lead_paragraph: GRAHAMSTOWN, South Africa -- Members of the Evidence Dance Company are serving as cultural ambassadors on their State Department-sponsored tour of Africa, but the flip side is that the Americans are being exposed to other cultures, too. "It's very much about learning from, as well as sharing with," said Nathan Holt, public affairs officer at the U.S. consulate in Cape Town, who was in Grahamstown Monday to watch the company perform for an audience of schoolchildren from surrounding areas. On their one day off in Senegal, a week ago, the troupe visited what had been a slave house on Gorée Island, just over a mile away from Dakar's harbor. "You read about this in history in school," said Arcell Cabaug, the associate artistic director of Evidence. "But it's very different standing there in the cell. You call feel the pain, imagine the screams. They don't teach you that."

headline.main: Evidence in Africa: The Dancers' Day Off
